subject: Re: [junit] Re: Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... Well, I think that you and I expect the same results.  A more reasonable test would involve running a mix of programs that do Java-ish things. They should
messageBody:
On Wed, 24 Sep 2003, Ron Jeffries wrote:

> It's time for a test. Someone who uses Java needs to do it -- that wouldn't
> be me. I could do it in Ruby, C#, or Smalltalk, none of which are very
> germane to this group. Something like this:
>
> Write a loop that times itself, using really short names. Duplicate it
> with really long names. Time the loops. Repeat until you're sure you've
> got data. I'd have them in the same program. It might be desirable to try
> it with one of the loops first in the source, then the other, just in
> case of garbage collection issues or things like that. Or it might not.
>
> I know what I expect to happen, but I don't know what /will/ happen.

Well, I think that you and I expect the same results. A more reasonable
test would involve running a mix of programs that do Java-ish things.
They should get loaded from disk, they should send messages to one
another, they should hang around in memory doing nothing much, they
should communicate over the Net.

Over the last ten years most of my work has involved the Internet. Our
servers spent most of their time waiting for communications; they
usually ran at a few percent of CPU. Whenever they didn't, we replaced
them with faster servers. The problem was always disk I/O, memory
footprint, network I/O. Any tests that I do will be biased towards that
world -- where I think that most Java applications live.

--
